document.text: Youngest son of Mrs. Willie A. Trent, died at his home near Old Courthouse of influenza on January 9. Nearly the entire family has bnen stricken down with influenzi during the past two weeks, and several of them are very ill now. Before the burial bi her son, Alvin, her little grandson, Thomas W yatt Bohannon, aged twoyears,died and the son and grandson were buried in the family burying ground Friday afternoon iu the same grave, funeral services b ing conducted by Rev. A. 8. J. Rice Mr. Trent was a kind and well beloved young m an and a member of Memorial Methodist church. He kept the Faith un til tbe end and said he had no murmur against the Lords will. lie was a devoted and affectionate son and brother, and he and his little nephew, Tommie, who rest under the sod, will be much missed in the family, by whom they were so well loved.

Mrs. Nannie Johnson, recording secre tary, took minutes. The Usher Board is planning for their anniver sary the second Sunday .in June. You are cordially invited to our Mothers Dfcy program on the second Sunday in May at 11 a.m. Our guest speaker will be the. Rev. H. O. Flood, and the Male Chorus will perform. document.text: Work of Japanese Girls. For Japans coronation ceremony of talshosal next November 27 pretty young women have been assisting in transplanting the young emerald rice plants in the sacred fields of the Mlkawa province. Half way to their knees in water, they toiled dally, like their less privileged sisters, at the work. Bending down, they laid the tiny shoots In place, and rising, sang sacred Shinto songs, tor the rice grains of the rare festival must be perfect in shape and colortrue seed pearls of the Way of the Gods. The girls are from sixteen to twenty- one years old. Of these things the papers took note. The photographers snapped them in their coming and do ing and going. Not only from the neighborhood but from afar have come insistent marriage proposals, and all but one are said to be en gaged and are to be married the day of the coronation.

document.text: Work of Angoumois Grain Moth. duced In weight and consequent sell ing value, but is often rendered  wholly unfit for human food and less valuable as food for live stock. A species of insects of which the parents are moths is found to be very destructive, this is the angoumois grain moth, the larvae of which devel ops entirely in the kernels of corn or other grain. The Southern farmer generally ap- I plies the term fly weevil to this spe cies to distinguish it from the rice or I black weevil, but the term is hardly I appropriate, because the adult flying j moth is simply the parents form oi the worm that feed3 in the grain. This species does not attack meal or j food products, but lives in the whole  grain, a single kernel of corn often  furnishing food for two or three larvae. During the year five or six gener- j ations of moths may be produced. ! Farmers commonly remark that grain  becomes infested In spring when large numbers of moths are seen flying in the granariesthus gaining for them the name fly weevil but in reality the grain ls generally first infested in j the field. These moths commence to emerge in April, and earlier in the warmer  sections, and succeeding generations I may mature about every six wqeks. Grain in the field ls evidently not I infested until nearly grown, or In such ! condition that the first moths mature i about when the grain is ripening It

document.text: wonderful structures of its hftyday have served for centuries as stone quarries, and nothing now remains ol their fabulous splendor. Aquileia, ret gal city of the empire, and later great seaport and industrial city, has vani lshed, in all likelihood for good. There remains from its golden dayB merely, a heterogeneous maBs of relics, statues, mosaics, columns, friezes from its parks and buildings lamps from its once famous factories, besides many homely survivals and nlcknacks. Grave tfl Past Achievement. Trieste, the great seaport ot today, is about twenty-five miles distant tfl the southwest. All the marks of ths prosperity and importance of Aquileia have fled to Trieste, In the east, and to Venice, in the west. The once busy harbor is choked with slit and drifting dunes, while rafts and fishing boats are almost the only craft that now thread the varying channels. The modi ern village, counting 2,300 people, is unhealthy on account of its rice fluids and is neglected and forgotten. Aquileia is a grave of past achlove- ment and a much-weathered monument of the world of the Roman ago Its museum is rich In trophies of Roman times and Its ancient cathedral and the remains of the patriarchs palace are Its most eloquent concrete memo rles. Aquileia, as Is much of the north ern and western coast of the Adriatic, is a rich field for archeologists and antiquarians. The city is said to have been colo nized by the Romans as a frontier fortress against the Celts In 183 B. In 168 A D. Marcus Aurelius made It one of the strongest fortified positions In the empire. During Hadrians reign its population reached the 600,000 mark. Attlla destroyed the city In 452 A. D., and It never recovered Its greatness. Aquileia was great and strong only throughout Its Roman history, when, during Its prime. It ranked immediately after the Eternal city Itself. Its fortunes were those of the Roman world, and modern Italy, looking back over the gulf of centu ries, feels Itself not only the descend ant, but also the heir of Latin Rome.

Mrs. Helen Stratton en tertained by playing Chop Sticks on the piano.  The meeting was called to order by Mrs. Dixie Staten, club president. Devoitons and prayer were given by JArs. Harden, who read from God in My Kitchen - article A Woman With No Trouble. . Mrs. Margaret Lee, sec retary, gave the minutes of the May meeting and the treasurers report was given and approved.

document.text: With eggs soaring higher and higher these days we must of necessity cur tail their use, and yet the family must have the sweet things and be supplied with a variety. A most delicious pud ding, which needs long, slow baking, is this Rice Pudding.Take a fourth of a cupful of rice, a half cupful of sugar and two quarts of rich milk with a half cupful of raisins or a few sliced sweet ap ples, put into a baking dish and set Into the oven. Stir often for the first hour or two, then let it brown. Bake for three hours. This is delicious without sauce, but a hard sauce fla vored with nutmeg makes it a dessert liked especially by the children and is a most wholesome one for them. Molasses Cookies.Take a cupful of shortening, a cupful of molasses and a cupful of brown sugar. Heat In a saucepan until well mixed, then add ginger or other spices to taste, a half teaspoonful of soda, dissolved In a little hot water and flour enough to roll but. If the mixture is cooled well before rolling It will handle better. Apple Sauce Cake.Take a cupful of brown sugar, a half cupful of short ening. a cupful of unsweetened apple sauce, made from cooking apples, a cupful of raisins, chopped, two tea spoonfuls of cocoa, a teaspoonful of cinnamon, a half teaspoonful each of cloves and nutmeg, two cupfuls of flour, sifted with a half teaspoonful of soda, and one teaspoonful of bak ing powder. Bake forty minutes in a shallow pan. This makes a good des- sert served with a lemon sauce or any desired flavor. Winter Shortcake __ Prepare a rich baking-powder biscuit dough make two cakes, rolling thin, spread one with butter and place the other on top, then when baked they are easilysplit without making them heavy. Use canned peaches, sliced oranges, or ba nanas or afiy fruit desired. Serve with cream and sugar. This same biscuit dough rolled thin, sprinkled with brown sugar and nuts, rolled, then cut like cinnamon rolls and baked are delicious little cakes for tea.

The custom with many thrifty house keepers is to use yellow napkins, which may be used during the fruit season, and stains will not show on them. When washing glass. Blip it sidewise into the water to avoid cracking. If a new silk skirt Is pressed with a hot Iron before wearing It will take out the stiffness and the rustle but keep It from cracking. Cushions filled with excelsior make a good back for softer cushions on tbe couch. Dampen a scorched spot, and If it Is not really burned, place In the sun, and it will become white again. 8tuffed Spanish Onions.Peel six even-sized onions and parboil in boil ing water until partly done. Drain and remove the centers, and stuff with sausage. Put some slices of bacon In the bottom of a baking dish, put a lit tle of the onion centers and cooked carrot over each and place on this tbe parboiled onipn. Add stock and hake until thoroughly tender. Instead of using raisins in the rice pudding try a few bits of chopped Can ton ginger. A tablespoonful to a quart of milk will be sufficient to give the pudding a flavor. Put your hyacinths for winter bloom ing in their glasses or potB before Oc tober is gone or theblooms will be late. document.text: With a pound of nice sweet suet one may prepare several good dishes. among them are Old - Fashioned Hash.  Brown one large onion well chopped in one-half cupful of suet, then add boiling water to ___ cover and six or eight medium-sized potatoes which have been diced. Stew the mixture for an hour, seasoning with salt and pepper. Potatoes With Dressing. Try out one cupful of suet in a baking pan and place peeled potatoes in one end to bake. After a half-hour add the following dressing Place a quart of bread crumbs in a crock and. pour over this a small quantity of soup stock if water is used add butter, then add one egg, a small onion chopped, salt and pepper to season. Bake the dressing with potatoes. When done remove the remaining fat and serve the potatoes and dressing with a green salad. Noodles. Place three-quarters of  cupful of ground suet in a kettle, try out and when the bits are brown re move them. Add three pints of water, salt and pepper and cook noodles in the kettle tightly covered for fifteen minutes. Vegetable Soup. To one cupful of suet add one large onion sliced and browned, and two quarts of soup broth prepared from beef bones, two large tomatoes or the equivalent in canned tomato, two carrots diced, a large tablespoonful of rice, a sprig of parsjey and a small turnip with a little cabbage if desired. Season well and simmer an hour. This is a deli clous and nourishing soup which will take the place of a main dish. Stuffed Onions. Cook large, uni form sized onions until nearly done. Scoop out the center and fill with the onion chopped and mixed with chopped suet, sage, bread crumbs and pepper and salt .to season. Bake, basting with a little tried out suet until a good rich brown. Rice With Suet. Boll a cupful of rice until tender in salted water bar ley may be used In place of the rice if preferred when cooked reserve one quart of the water with the rice and add one cupful of chopped suet. Sea son with Onion, salt and pepper and cook one-lmlf hour.

document.text: Willie Josiah LeGrand Willie Josiah LeGrand, 83, of Appomattox, Va., died at St. Johns Nursing Home in Lynch burg, Virginia, at 1245 p.m,. Tuesday, January 19, after a pro longed illness. He was bom in Appomattox, January 17,1882 and was a life long resident. He was the son of Thomas Edward and Sarah Ann LeGrand and a faithful member of Liberty Baptist Church. He was a retired farmer and busi nessman. He is survived by his widow, Mrs. Lula Drinkard LeGrand and four daughters Mary Ann Le Grand, Lynchburg Mrs. Lester C. Furney, Clearwater, Florida Mrs. L- Carter, Wellesley, Mas sachusetts, Mrs. Forrest L. Yeak- ley, Richmond and three sons Thomas E. LeGrand and Walter H. LeGrand, Appomattox and Alfred A. LeGrand, of Boydton, Va. Also surviving are seven grand children and two sisters, Mrs. W. A. Kelley, of Culpeper, Va. and Mrs. W. D. Mason, of Rice, Va. and a number of nieces and nephews. The body will lie in state at Robinson Funeral Home, Appo mattox. Funeral services will be con ducted from Liberty Bapt i s t Church at 330 p.m. Thursday with burial in Liberty Cemetery.

document.text: William Henry Weaver William Henry Weaver, 58, Madison Street, died Thursday morning at his residence. He was the husband of Loretta Wade Weaver. Born in Prince Edward County, he was a son of Ethel Holly Weaver, Madrid Island, Fla., and the late Charles Henry Weaver. . He was a veteran of World War II and a member of the Baptist church. In addition to his wife and mother, he is survived by three brothers, Eugene W eaver, Pamplin, and Mack Thomas Weaver and Melvin Lester Weaver, both of Florida, and a sister, Frances Louise Hedricks of Georgia. Grayeside services were conducted at 1 p.m. Saturday in Trinity Memorial Gardens, Rice, by the Rev. Rtinald L. Freeman. Whitten Park Avenue Chapel was in charge of arrangements.

document.text: Whooping cough is prevalent in this section. Mr. C. M. Strattons little girl has been very ill with whooping cough, so much so that for a time its life despared of.  Dr, Rrice was was promptly called ih,who soon checked the disease, and the little one is now restored to health. Mr. T. J. Stratton State inspec tor and sampler of fertilizers, has completed his labors for the sprjng season. Mr. Stratton reports that fertilizers have been very largely used all over the State this spring, and that he is satisfied that. Appo mattox farmers buy a larger per cent, of their goods direct from first lids for Gash, ilittu tile fui iiiefs of any, other section, of the State. Miss Belle Porter, of Farmville, who is visiting M ibb Lizzie Rice, was quite ill last week. Our people are jubilant over the result of the late election. The old Stonewall district did nobly, and is entitled to the banner. We are for Hoge Tyler for Gov ernor, Taylor Berry, of the old Dem ocratic free State of Amherst, for Lieutenant Governor, and for Thos. lit Martin for United States Senator. Ey r. Chap Jones was in the neigh borhood last Sunday. The Dr. visits us quite often of late. We are always glad to see him, but we cant help but think that there. is a lady stopping here to whom we are in debted for his frequent visits. S tonewall . Spanish Oaks, Va., June 7.

document.text: Who Controls Rice Supply Controls Asiatic Destiny Rice is the most important food in the world. To many Americans, that state ment seems a gross exaggeration but to most of the peoples of the world, it is simply a statement of fact which has been true through out the entire history of civilization and is just as true today. Rice is today, as it has always been, the basic food of more than half of the worlds population. In the Orient, rice is virtually the only food of millions of peopletheir means of sustaining life. The supply of rice is a matter of life or death for millions of people. He, who controls the supply of rice, will control the destiny of the entire Asiatic orbit. The most im portant thing to the majority of the people of Asia is not Democracy, nor Communism, nor any political ideology  but food, which means life itself. And in most of Asia, food is rice.

document.text: Whin Qas Rationing Comas, Haros How to Save Fuel DETROIT.With the anticipated gasoline shortage, particularly in the Midwest, the engineering division of the Chrysler corporation has con ducted tests to demonstrate how gasoline savings up to 70 per cent can be achieved. W. B. Rice, director of service, reported that the s ret of the sav ings lay in 1. Proper tuhe-up of the car, in cluding ignition, carburetion, cooling system, oil change and chassis lu brication, and steering and brake adjustments. 2. Employment of proper driving techniques in handling foot throttle and brakes. Tests showed that the first 10 per cent of savings were achieved by a tune-up of the car, Rice reported. Moderate acceleration and brak ing showed a 60 per cent greater mileage over the quick stop and start artists, he added. One test over a 10-mile course in heavy traffic in Detroit showed that the moderate starting and stopping driver made 50 per cent fewer stops and averaged only 2 per cent slower speed.

document.text: While the corn season lasts there are many most appetizing dishes which may be made from it or In combination with oth er foods. Fried Corn.Cook ba con for the family, then Into the hot bacon fat turn in corn cut from half a dozen ears, stir and mix well then, add a half-cupful of water, cover and cook slowly until tender. Segson with pepper and more salt if needed. Corn and Tomatoes.Cut the corn from the cob and stew until nearly dry, add a third as much stewed to matoes a3 corn, and season, using a teaspaonful of vinegar, a teaspoonful each of butter and sugar, and salt and pepper to taste, to one pint of toma toes. Serve hot. This is a favorite combination with some cooks to put up in cans for winter.  Economical Cake,Sift together one cupful of flour, two-thirds of a cupful of sugar, one teaspoonful of baking powder and a Uttle salt. In a half plat measuring cup put a tablespoon ful of melted butter, drop in one egg, and fill the cup with milk. Stir into flic dry ingredients and beat rapidly two or three minutes. Flavor as de sired. Bake in a loaf. When baking cake, fruit juice may be used In .place of milk, which will result in a moist, finely flavored eake. Corn for the table, if cooked over steam is much better flavored than that allowed to cook in water. Add peanut butter when cooking fried potatoes, using a tablespoonful to the fat in the pan. It adds variety, nnd where the flavor Is liked makes an appetizing dish. Pure of Summer Squash.Slice three onions and cover with two quarts of cold water when boiling, add a large summer squash cut in thin slices. Let simmer slowly for two hours, then rub through a sieve. Mix one tablespoonfq of ground rice or corn starch with a cupful of milk or tablespoonful of butter and season ings cook until smooth and add to the soup. Serve hot.

document.text: While Mr. B e r k l e y Wool- ride was attempting to mount lone of Mr. Joe OBriens horses last Sunday the animal bit him on the calf of the leg, causing a very painful wound and keep ing Mr. Woolridge from his  post of duty for several days _ r. Joel Hubbard, mail car rier on route 1, is seriously ill at his home. He returned home from his route last Wed nesday feeling very unwell He was in bed all day Thurs day and on Friday morning it was seen that he had received a paralytic stroke As we go to press he is said to be very low. The district board at Roa noke has reversed the Looal Board of Lynchburg in defer rin g registrants who have be-  coire married since May 18th last and now puts the newly weds in class 1. There are quiteanuinBer of these cases before the district board from this county, and just what will happen to our newly-weds is not known. Beginning next Sunday a. m. Bro. Callabam will preach a series of sermons on the origin, progress and present status of the Methodist Episcopal church, There will be nothing narrow or of the sectarian spirit in these set mons These sermons are given for general enlighten-1 ment on this subject. Every body invited to attend these services and friends and mem bers are urged to be present Sunday evening at 73U Miss Gold, of the faculty of A. A. H. 8, will conduct the Epworth  League. Special program for the evening. Mrs. 8. R. Martin, who has been in febbie health for some time, passed away Sunday atl her home near Trinity Ohurch in the 67th year of her age. The deceased was a woman of many virtues, full of the spirit of her Master and she wilt be missed by her c h u r c h and neighbors. She is survived by her husband, wLo is Supervisor for Stonewall district, and one son, Mr. Thomas Martin, of Ap pomattox. Her remains wtrej interred at her late home in the  presence of a very large crowd of friends and members of her family. Her pastor, Rev. A. 8.  J. Rice, assisted by Rev. J. M. Street, conducted the service. Tbe father of the deceased was  present, aged 92 years and ac live. _ _______
